Sorry, but a “hacker” isn’t going to help you in the slightest little bit. They will take your money and I hope you have plenty if you contact them. Phone monitoring applications do exist, but they have to be installed by hand - with your phone in the perpetrator’s hands. This cannot be done remotely and requires jailbreaking or “rooting” the phone. So if you haven’t given your phone to someone, you are probably safe. Let’s say you aren’t sure if someone borrowed your phone and did this. Don’t you have a lock code on your phone? No? Well, then you are open to such things happening. While a lock code isn’t absolute security, it will keep someone from being able to install stuff on your phone if they just pick it up for a couple of minutes at a bar or at the office. So how do you tell if you have one of these apps installed on your phone? It is extremely difficult to be sure. Two things that will be a clue are the battery life and temperature. Did your phone suddenly get so your phone needs to be charged more often? Is your phone warm when you pick it up? Both of these indicate that something is going on with your phone that you may not be aware of. OK, what do you do? Here is the hard part. Unless you are very, very lucky, removing one of these apps is extremely difficult and time consuming. You cannot simply back up your phone, wipe it back to factory state and restore. You would be restoring the spyware app. You need to basically wipe your phone and by hand transfer everything you need back to the phone one item at a time. There are ways to do this with a backup and external storage, but none of it is easy for either iPhone or Android. No, someone cannot do this “for” you remotely. The apps cannot be removed remotely and really cannot be removed at all without wiping the phone. If someone says they can fix this problem for you and only charge you $100 they are robbing you and you probably do not have a spyware app on your phone at all.

Somebody is tracking your mobile phone, and they have to —your phone company tracks the phone all the time because if they didn’t they couldn’t provide a service at a sensible price. They do have a legal obligation in most countries not to misuse the data and to respect your privacy, so it isn’t anything to worry about. In most cases it is only computers that know where you are and the information is used only to provide the service. It is not normally made accessible to anyone, even within the phone company. As for anyone else, it is impossible to tell if the Police or security services are tracking your phone and that’s just as it should be. If people could tell then criminals would have a free alert that they were being tracked. This makes it undesirable for it to be possible to tell. If you aren’t a criminal of any kind then who cares if the Police or the security services are tracking your phone? If you have a smart-phone then it may be possible for a criminal to track it in some circumstances, but these are limited and if you look after the phone and its software properly you won’t be affected. In theory a smart-phone virus could track your phone and report to somebody over the internet connection. To avoid this the following should be adequate: Don’t download software from sources that might not be trustworthy.Keep your phone OS as up-to-date as you can.Learn about the better known security sites and sign up to a couple of their newsletters so you are made aware if there is a problem with your model of phone.Be sensible about web sites you visit. Some porn sites and many hackers’ sites are a great way to pick up a virus, spyware or a trojan. Don’t go there with your phone’s browser.Don’t let anyone get hold of the phone’s serial number, known as the IMEI number in most countries.The other issue with smart-phones is your privacy settings. Check them and if you don’t understand them call the phone company’s customer services and ask them to help you. In some cases anyone who has your phone number could track the phone if you haven’t set your privacy settings properly. Mostly this is so you can let friends track your phone so, for example, they can invite you to join them if they are having lunch in a restaurant near your location. This is a great little service that can be an aid to your social life, but you have to learn about how to set it up properly to prevent complete strangers from tracking you.

I remember there was a rumour back in the day, that if your calls are monitored (or intercepted by authorities), you will hear a clicking sound when the line is connected. Obviously, this is not true, and would go against the whole point of legal interception. Here is how it works, and why you will never be able to tell if you are monitored (by authorities, anything else must be done via applications as others said before). During call setup, your call goes through 4 phases: Establishing a ling between a tower and your deviceEstablishing a link between the tower and the serverEstablishing a link between the server (the same or different, depending if you are in the same cell as the called party) and a towerEstablishing the link between the second tower and the called party’s phoneStep 1 & 2, and 3 & 4 are called legs. Between step 2 & 3, the server starts searching for B party’s data (in their Home Location Register, wthe adress of which can be calculated from the called number). This HLR will send back data to establish the 2nd leg and connect the call - it will also send information about stuff like call forwarding, call waiting services, and legal interception (the same happens for calling party as well). If B is marked for interception, then during the 3rd step, a third leg is created, connecting the call to the authorities as well. At this point, B party still doesn’t have “line”, meaning they can’t hear anything from the process. Additionally, hearing any sound (like the ringing tone you hear before the called party picks up) is played when the server is intructed to play it - it can be disabled completely as well, but the point is, for legal interception, this “play tone” command is never sent. Also, the legal interception line is strictly one-way: there is no voice channel established to send back any data. It is virtually impossible to detect legal interception by the user, unless someone makes some error in the call setup code and accidentally opens up the voice channel or sends back some “play tone” command. PS: back in the days, when there was a big “race” on who can connect calls faster (we are talking about milliseconds here, like in Formula 1), Huawei actually made a feature where they sent this play tone command and connected the voice channel before both sides sent the OK signal, indicating the connection has been established between the two parties. In this cases, you might have experienced that you only hear the end of the greeting from the other party (like “lo” from “Hello”). It’s a different story, it’s basically the same if your car would allow you to start the engine before turning the key all the way or pressing the pedal fully.

You probably can’t. First thing you should realise is that you most likely aren’t being watched. TV and Movies depict hacking as agents sitting in dimly lit rooms that just press a button to get access to everything and stream your phone but this is simply not true (at least we don’t think it is @NSA.) Apple is famous for security of their products so watching your screen or even remotely stealing data is incredibly unlikely, i can’t comment for android or other operating systems but i assume they are also very secure. Most attacks will be in the form of “phishing attacks” where an attacker will send you a fake email claiming to be from Apple or Google asking you to reset your password. If your on iPhone and have iCloud enabled, once an attacker has your AppleId they can easily get access to most of your phones data (photos, contacts, sms ect.) Local attacks would be coming from someone on the same network as you, programs like Wireshark can be used to see network traffic and detect anything suspicious, but assuming nobody you live with or that uses your internet connection has advanced degrees and experience in networking or software engineering and an intent, nobody will be doing this to you. So while you can’t really detect attacks there are steps you can take to prevent them. Prevention of Phishing attacks Inspect any email coming from companies by clicking into the “from” field and looking around, most of the time if its a phishing attempt there will be a different email listed.Don’t click into links from emails. If you get an email from Apple asking you to take actions, go to the Apple website yourself, if action really needs to be taken websites will alert you once logging in most of the time.Inspect SSL Certificates of websites you click on. Look for the green “Secure” icon in the left hand side of the URL bar, clicking on it shows info about the website. Secure parts of a website should also show the company name in green in the URL Bar. Getting this requires proof that the registrar is who they say they are.Inspect the URL of the page you are going to, some attackers are so bad at this they will use completely random URLs, but some are smarter and might use something like “app1e.com”, notice the 1 instead of the l.Just in general prevent giving out information/passwords through emails or links in emails you receive. Stay safe.

There are two main ways a person can monitor a phone. The first way is to intercept the signals being sent by your phone and break the encryption. If someone is doing this, you have no way of knowing. However, this method requires a significant amount of resources, so its usually only done by government agencies and other similar organizations, so the chances that a hacker not affiliated with a government or other powerful entity will use this method is minuscule. If you are concerned, you can switch your device to airplane mode, which will mean that no signals will be emitted from your phone. The second way, on the other hand, is far easier to do and requires less resources. It involves loading an application on your phone remotely that can retrieve and send whatever data they would like to get. The way to check for this is to open up your settings and see what applications are running. Don’t just check what apps are downloaded because you can covertly download applications on iPhones that have been jailbroken or Android devices. If there is something running that shouldn’t be (not associated with an app or the operating system), you are being monitored and should either destroy your phone or determine how that application was downloaded. The way to prevent this from happening is to keep Bluetooth off unless you trust all the devices within range, updating your phone as soon as possible, and be alert to phishing scams and/or emails that look suspicious (although they usually get filtered out to spam).

There are a number of quick, easy methods you can employ to make sure no one is spying on your phone. If your battery is draining more quickly than usual, tracking software could be running in the background.--Unless you're playing a bunch of games on your phone, your battery draining quickly could be a sign that you're being tracked.-- This is especially true when your phone is taking longer to charge. A longer charge time might indicate that an intensive app -- like a monitoring app -- is running. If your phone constantly feels warm, spy software could be running.-- Your phone will get warm from time to time as it runs intense software like games, but if you aren't running anything other than Facebook and your phone feels like it could fry an egg, you could be the victim of spy software. -- This is not applicable while you are charging your device -- some phones just get hot as the battery charges. However, if a phone becomes really warm to the touch, it may be a result of your phone being over-worked, and this might mean that a spyware application is running. If your phone calls have been filled with strange noises or echoing lately, somebody might be listening in.-- If you've never had issues with your phone echoing during calls in the past, but you are now, you might have an uninvited guest on your phone call.

response.answer_text: If it's being done legally, with a warrant, you can't. The tracking happens deep in the network, there is no “hack” or hidden software on your phone. If it's being done illegally, there are some subtle things, but those same things can occur on a phone not being tracked. Shorter battery life, long connect times after you push the SEND key, A sudden inexplicable change in signal strength, the number of bars your phone displays. But all of those things occur normally in a network sometimes. If you're worried about hidden software on the phone, you can check storage/memory usage to see if there is anything you don't recognize. You can go online and look at your detailed bill to see if there has been an unusual increase in SMS or data usage. if your phone is behaving strangely, print out your contacts and other important information, and do a factory reset. See if the odd behavior stops. Never click “a"I accept” or “"I agree” to anything, unless you know what it is. Im not familiar with Android, but on Apple you can disable ALL location based services. But as I said, there is no way to tell for sure.

There are, unfortunately, many ways to spy on your phone. I’ll go from broader to the closest to your phone: Internet data: the US gvt - and other big organization - are capable of intercepting & storing your messages. You have no direct power over them. You can circumvent their monitoring by using cryptography but you’ll end up looking more suspiciousPhone Service Provider : I worked for them, they have access to the “pipes” carrying you data, they can see / act on what you say / message / send, you have very limited control over thatPhone Cloning : this is rather advanced and unusual hacking, but basically someone can copy your IMSI (subscriber identifier) to create a clone of your phone on the network and recieve call / SMS as if they were youPhone Tapping : I saw that once, someone with access to your phone or account can install a spy software giving access to the phone’s data, location, you name it. Such app provide the thieve real time data.Direct Access : gvt officials are legally capable of asking you to hand over your device or its data unencrypted in most countries.Most of the time, you have little to no chance of detecting a data leak when it happens. If you’re suspecting something here’s my advice: 1. ask you service provider for a new SIM card 2. reset your phone to factory settings (which will remove any spy program if any) 3. always use 2 factor authentication on all your accounts (supported by Google, Twitter, Facebook etc.) If you can’t, use different password for each apps 4. crypt your phone internal storage (easy on android, IDK on IOS) 5. even turned off, your phone can still be “seen” on the network. if you truely want to disapear, remove both SIM & Battery. Good Luck :-)

Unless there is a form of spyware or malware on your mobile device, you will not be able to. Once the signal has left your phone via wifi or cell signal, it's not expected to return. Therefore your phone will never know that the information you sent was diverted before reaching its intended destination.  If there is an actual application on your mobile device, it's still may be difficult to tell. Andriod devices are notoriously open and iPhones are notoriously locked down.  One way to tell if something out of the ordinary is going on is to: route your phones connection through your computer, and turn off the cellular signal so that the phone can only connect to the Internet via the wifi of you computer. Then open a network logger like WireShark or Fiddler depending on PC or Mac. You'll see the destination of each expected piece of information sent, but this still won't prevent the data from being re-routed before reaching its destination.
